docs.lead_paragraph: Under the cost-cutting pressure of competition and managed care, two-thirds of the nation's private hospitals that are equipped to take in mentally ill patients dump them on financially strapped public hospitals and community services, says a study to be published on Wednesday in the journal Health Services Research. In a nationwide analysis of such practices, the authors, Robert Dorwart, a professor of psychiatry at Harvard Medical School, and Mark Schlesinger, an economist at the Yale School of Medicine, say hospitals sometimes reject mentally ill patients simply by denying admission to the great majority who have no other medical problem.

docs.lead_paragraph: NO ONE was more skeptical about using magnets for pain relief than Dr. Carlos Vallbona, former chairman of the department of community medicine at Baylor College of Medicine in Houston. So Dr. Vallbona was amazed when a study he did found that small, low intensity magnets worked, at least for patients experiencing symptoms that can develop years after polio. Dr. Vallbona had long been fascinated by testimonials about magnets from his patients, and even from medical leaders. But his interest in magnet therapy became more serious in 1994 when he and a colleague, Carlton F. Hazlewood, tried them for their own knee pain. The pain was gone in minutes. ''That was too good to be true,'' Dr. Vallbona said.

docs.lead_paragraph: A year after New York State lawmakers gave their blessing to the plan, the Westchester County Medical Center is prepared to transform itself from a government-run hospital to a quasi-independent entity, a move that officials hope will make the hospital stronger and more competitive in the world of managed health care. After pressing the Legislature for years to free the hospital from the tight restrictions that accompany government control, hospital officials got what they wanted in January. Lawmakers passed a bill allowing the county to establish a public benefit corporation -- a nonprofit organization with its own board of directors -- to run the hospital.

docs.lead_paragraph: Over the last year, Oxford Health Plans Inc. has fallen seriously behind in paying doctors and hospitals, owing hundreds of millions of dollars. Blaming its new computer system, Oxford counseled patience and made repeated assurances that the snarls were being addressed. The alibi is starting to fray. A growing number of regulators, investors, doctors and consultants who are looking behind the numbers are reaching the conclusion that Oxford may have been too quick to place the blame for its problems, and the chaos at the company, on its computer system alone.

headline.main: INSURER IN AGONY: Behind the Bleeding at Oxford -- A special report; Giant H.M.O. Becomes the Victim of Its Own Ambition

docs.lead_paragraph: STEPHEN F. WIGGINS was the kind of chief executive who knew how to work a room. Never one to forget a name and face, he would charm the analysts who flocked to hear him expound on Oxford Health Plans Inc., the company he founded, and on the state of managed care. These days, Mr. Wiggins has a lot of explaining to do. Oxford has been in the news a lot lately for the sizable charge to earnings it announced in October because of what were described as snarls in processing its bills. And when investors showed up at the Pierre Hotel in Manhattan on Thursday for the BancAmerica Robertson Stephens Medical Conference, they were stunned to learn that Mr. Wiggins had canceled his presentation. Analysts who later called the company to inquire could not get their calls returned.

headline.main: Market Place ; Silence from Oxford Health is making investors nervous.

docs.lead_paragraph: By legislation, regulation and exhortation, President Clinton has generated a remarkable number of seemingly modest initiatives. Though often derided as political gestures, some of the little ideas, from advocating school uniforms to insuring overnight hospital stays for new mothers, have had significant influence around the country. Taken together, Mr. Clinton's initiatives have produced coherent and substantial changes in health care, and to a lesser extent in education and social services.

headline.main: How a Presidency Was Defined By the Thousand Parts of Its Sum

docs.abstract: On the Record, second of two articles on Pres Clinton's second term, finds Clinton is proving himself to be incremental President, accomplishing piecemeal some of what he cannot do all at once, and many political opponents who defeated him in head-on fights now worry that he is achieving goals by other means; by legislation, regulation and exhortation, he has generated remarkable number of seemingly modest initiatives that have had significant influence nationwide, even though they have been derided as political gestures; he says, in New York Times interview, that his so-called small ideas make big difference, maintaining with many aides that they loom large in classrooms and at dinner tables everywhere else; dealt series of blows at end of Congress's last session, belittled as lame duck and beset by allegations of campaign finance abuses, Clinton is trying to retain political initiative and his grip on public's attention by relying on approaches learned from hard experiences of first term; since 1995, he has continuoulsy experimented with powers of his office to generate initiatives, relying more on executive orders and bully pulpit; photos (L)
